case_name: Dafedar Niranjan Singh and Major Bhagwant Singh v. Deputy Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 1, 1958, of the Deputy Custodian-General, Evacuee Property, New Delhi, in No. 1017-R Judl Punj.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 1, 1958, of the Deputy Custodian-General, Evacuee Property, New Delhi, in No. 1017-R Judl Punj.

facts.text: Dafedar Niranjan Singh, the first appellant, owned houses Nos. 915 and 916 in Patiala.

anchor.surface_text: One Dafedar Niranjan Singh, the first appellant herein, owned houses Nos. 915 and 916 situate in the town of Patiala.

facts.text: During the latter part of 1948, Custodian of Evacuee Property, Patiala, took possession of houses Nos. 915 and 916 under Ordinance IX of 2004 as evacuee properties.

anchor.surface_text: During the latter part of 1948, the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Patiala, took possession of the said houses under the provisions of the Patiala Evacuees  Administration of Property  Ordinance of Samvat 2004  No. IX of 2004   hereinafter referred to as Ordinance IX of 2004 , on the ground that they were evacuee properties.

facts.text: On January 27, 1949, Dafedar Niranjan Singh filed a claim petition before the Custodian alleging properties belonged to him by inheritance.

anchor.surface_text: On January 27, 1949, Dafedar Niranjan Singh filed a claim petition before the said Custodian alleging that the said properties belonged to him by inheritance.

facts.text: Custodian by order dated June 6, 1949, allowed the claim and released the properties.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian by order dated June 6, 1949, allowed the claim and released the said properties.

facts.text: Order communicated to Assistant Custodian on June 7, 1949, and houses released.

anchor.surface_text: This order was companymunicated to the Assistant Custodian on June 7, 1949, and pursuant to that order the said houses were released.

facts.text: On June 9, 1955, first appellant sold part of properties to Major Bhagwant Singh for Rs. 6,000.

anchor.surface_text: On June 9, 1955, the first appellant sold a part of the said properties to Major Bhagwant Singh, the second appellant herein, for Rs. 6,000.

facts.text: On June 21, 1949, Ordinance IX of 2004 repealed by Ordinance No. XIII of 2006.

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1949, Ordinance IX of 2004 was repealed by the Patiala and East Punjab States Union Ordinance No. XIII of Samvat 2006  hereinafter referred to as Ordinance No. XIII of 2006  which was in its turn repealed by the Patiala and East Punjab State Union Ordinance No. XVII of 2006  hereinafter referred to as Ordinance No. XVII of 2006 .

facts.text: On October 18, 1949, Ordinance No. XVII of 2006 repealed by Central Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1949, Ordinance No. XVII of 2006 was also repealed by Central Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949, under which for the first time the office of Custodian-General was created.

facts.text: Central Ordinance replaced by Administration of Evacuee Property Act No. XXXI of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This Central Ordinance was replaced by the Administration of Evacuee Property Act  No. XXXI of 1950 .

facts.text: On December 24, 1955, Litigation Inspector filed application for review of June 6, 1949 order before Custodian Patiala.

anchor.surface_text: On December 24, 1955, i.e., more than six years after the order of the Custodian, the Litigation Inspector of Evacuee Properties filed an application before the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Patiala, for review of the order of the Custodian dated June 6, 1949.

facts.text: During pendency of review application, powers of Custodian and Additional Custodian for review and revision under s.26 taken away by Amendment Act XCI of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that application, the powers of the Custodian and the Additional Custodian of Evacuee Property of review and revision under s. 26 of the Act were taken away by the Administration of Evacuee Property  Amendment  Act XCI of 1956.

facts.text: On April 2, 1957, Additional Custodian submitted case to Custodian-General for suo motu action under s.27.

anchor.surface_text: On April 2, 1957, the Additional Custodian submitted the case to the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property to enable him to take action suo motu under s. 27 of the Act.

facts.text: On May 24, 1957, Deputy Custodian-General issued notice to appellants to show cause why 1949 order be revised.

anchor.surface_text: On May 24, 1957, the Deputy Custodian-General, to whom the powers of the Custodian-General in that behalf had been delegated, issued numberice to the appellants to show cause why the order of the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Patiala, dated June 6, 1949, be number revised.

facts.text: On February 1, 1958, Deputy Custodian-General set aside June 6, 1949 order and remanded for enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: On February 1, 1958, after hearing the parties, the Deputy Custodian General, set aside the order of the Custodian dated June 6, 1949, and remanded the case to the Custodian for further enquiry.

facts.text: Present appeal by special leave directed against February 1, 1958 order.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal by special leave was directed against the said order.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 66 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 66 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 8, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the order of the Deputy Custodian-General of Evacuee Property, India, dated February 1, 1958,

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act No. XXXI of 1950 came into force on April 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 was repealed by the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  No. XXXI of 1950   hereinafter called the Act , which came into force on April 17, 1950.

facts.text: Court sets aside order of Custodian-General and restores order of Custodian dated June 6, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the Custodian-General is set aside and that of the Custodian dated June 6, 1949, is restored.

facts.text: Custodian-General found unbroken chain of fiction deeming 1949 order under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian- General found an unbroken chain of fiction leading to the companyclusion that the order dated June 6, 1949, made by the Custodian must be deemed to be an order made by the Custodian in exercise of the powers companyferred on him under the Act and, therefore, was subject to the revisional jurisdiction of the Custodian-General under s. 27 of the Act.

facts.text: No appeal filed against June 6, 1949 order to District Judge under Ordinance XXVII.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, numberappeal was filed against the order of the Custodian to the District Judge and, therefore, the said order had become final under s. 28.

issues.text: Whether the deeming provisions of the repealing Ordinances and Acts culminating in s. 58(3) of the Act apply only to things done or action taken by the Custodian in exercise of his administrative powers and not to orders made by him in exercise of his judicial powers?

anchor.surface_text: The deeming provisions of the repealing. Ordinances and Acts culminating in s. 58 3  of the Act apply only to things done or action taken by the Custodian in exercise of his administrative powers and not to orders made by him in exercise of his judicial powers.

issues.text: Whether the order passed by the Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004 can be deemed to be an order passed under the Act, or was the chain of fiction broken when Ordinance No. XIII of 2006 was issued?

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004 cannot be deemed to be an order passed under the Act, as the chain of fiction was broken when Ordinance No. XIII of 2006 was issued.

issues.text: Whether Section 58(3) of the Act expressly saves the previous operation of Ordinance XXVII of 1949 or any corresponding law, such that orders that had become final under the said Ordinance could not be revised under s. 27 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Section 58 3  of the Act expressly saves the previous operation of Ordinance XXVII of 1949 or any corresponding law, and, therefore, the orders that had become final under the said Ordinance could not be revised under s. 27 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004 had no jurisdiction to allow the claim of the first appellant such that the said order was a nullity and could be vacated by the Custodian-General at any time under s. 27 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State in addition to contesting the said arguments, further submitted that the Custodian under Ordinance IX of 2004 had no jurisdiction to allow the claim of the first appellant and, therefore, the said order was nullity with the result, the Custodian-General could vacate it at any time under s. 27 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The order dated June 6, 1949, made by the Custodian must be deemed to be an order made by the Custodian in exercise of the powers conferred on him under the Act and therefore was subject to the revisional jurisdiction of the Custodian-General under s. 27 of the Act due to unbroken chain of fiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian- General found an unbroken chain of fiction leading to the conclusion that the order dated June 6, 1949, made by the Custodian must be deemed to be an order made by the Custodian in exercise of the powers conferred on him under the Act and, therefore, was subject to the revisional jurisdiction of the Custodian-General under s. 27 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 was repealed and reenacted by the Act of 1950 in substantially the same terms, therefore repeal by implication only of omitted provisions like proviso to s.6 of Ordinance IX, making order nullity revisable under s.27.

anchor.surface_text: The argument was that Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 was repealed and reenacted by the Act of 1950 in substantially the same terms, and, therefore, a repeal by implication was effectuated only of those provisions which were omitted from reenactment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Raised first time in Supreme Court, not in lower proceedings or statement of case; s.27 retrospective only per s.58(3) which saves finality.

arguments.claim: Deeming provisions in s.58(3) apply to judicial orders, not confined to administrative acts.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument of learned counsel for the appellant, namely, that the operation of s. 58 3  of the Act shall be confined only to administrative acts done by the Custodian under the earlier Ordinances, was specifically raised before this Court and negatived by it in Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi.

arguments.claim: No deeming of Custodian's order under Ordinance IX as sub-s.7 s.10 Ordinance XIII deems only Claims Officer orders for purpose of appeal/revision.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. 7  of s. 10 only provided that orders passed by the Claims Officer under Ordinance No. IX of 2004 should be deemed to have been passed under sub-s.  4  of s. 10 of Ordinance No. XIII of 2006 for the purpose of appeal or revision.

arguments.claim: Order became final under s.28 Ordinance XXVII as no appeal to District Judge; s.58(3) saves previous operation including finality, second part subject to first.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, no appeal was filed against the order of the Custodian to the District Judge and, therefore, the said order had become final under s. 28. ... The first part says that the repeal by the Act of the said Ordinance shall not affect the previous operation of the said Ordinance.

arguments.claim: Provisions touching rights in existence or finality at passing of statute not retrospective absent express enactment or necessary intendment.

anchor.surface_text: provisions which touch a right in existence at the passing of the statute are not to be applied retrospectively in the absence of express enactment or necessary intendment. ... provisions which, if applied retrospectively, would deprive of their existing finality Orders which, when the statute came into force, were final.

arguments.claim: Indira Sohan Lal distinguished as there application pending, no finality attained before Act; here order final before Act.

anchor.surface_text: There, unlike here, an application made to the Additional Custodian of Evacuee Property on March 20, 1948, was not disposed of until March 20, 1952 ... In the present case the order made by the Custodian ... had become final before the Act of 1950 came into force.

arguments.claim: Punjab High Court in Janki Prasad incorrectly appreciated s.58(3); earlier order not deemed under Act to allow review.

anchor.surface_text: We think, with respect to the learned Judges, that they have not correctly appreciated the scope of the provisions of s. 58 3  of the Act of 1950.

holdings.text: The first argument that the deeming provisions of s. 58(3) of the Act apply only to administrative acts and not to judicial orders is rejected, as negatived in Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument of learned counsel for the appellant, namely, that the operation of s. 58 3  of the Act shall be confined only to administrative acts done by the Custodian under the earlier Ordinances, was specifically raised before this Court and negatived by it in Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi 1 . [...] In view of this decision nothing further need be said on the first point and it is, therefore, rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly follows binding precedent in Indira Sohan Lal where similar contention that deeming limited to administrative acts was rejected, holding it applies to judicial orders.

holdings.text: The chain of fiction deeming the 1949 Custodian order under the Act is broken at Ordinance No. XIII of 2006, as sub-s.7 of s.10 deems only orders passed by Claims Officer under Ordinance IX of 2004, not by Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: There is force in the second contention. The Custodian- General found an unbroken chain of fiction [...] But the history of the legislation [...] shows that the said chain had broken even during the period when Ordinance No. XIII of 2006 was in force. [...] Sub-s. 7 of s. 10 only provided that orders passed by the Claims Officer under Ordinance No. IX of 2004 should be deemed [...] We, therefore, accept this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of sub-s.7 s.10 Ordinance XIII limits deeming to Claims Officer orders only, for purpose of appeal/revision; Custodian order not covered, breaking chain to subsequent laws.

holdings.text: The order of June 6, 1949 became final under s.28 of Ordinance XXVII of 1949 as no appeal filed; s.58(3) of the Act saves previous operation of the Ordinance including finality, preventing revision under s.27.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, no appeal was filed against the order of the Custodian to the District Judge and, therefore, the said order had become final under s. 28. [...] The first part says that the repeal by the Act of the said Ordinance shall not affect the previous operation of the said Ordinance [...] provisions which touch a right in existence at the passing of the statute are not to be applied retrospectively [...] We, therefore, accept the third contention of learned counsel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.58(3) has two parts: first saves previous operation (finality under s.28); second deeming subject thereto; no retrospective effect depriving finality without express words, per Delhi Cloth & General Mills precedent.

holdings.text: Section 27 of the Act permits revision only of orders made or deemed under the Act that had not become final before it came into force; cannot revise final orders under previous laws due to s.58(3).

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we find any force in the argument of learned counsel for the State that under s. 27 of the Act, the Custodian- General may at any time revise the order of any Custodian and, therefore, the Custodian-General can revise without any limit of time any order made by any Custodian under any previous law. Section 27 of the Act can be given retrospective operation only to the extent permitted by s. 58 3  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27's scope ('any time', 'any Custodian') confined by s.58(3) savings of prior finality; retrospective only per deeming limits.

holdings.text: The contention that the 1949 order was a nullity due to lack of jurisdiction under Ordinance IX of 2004 cannot be raised for first time in Supreme Court; even if true, Custodian-General lacks power to vacate final prior orders.

anchor.surface_text: This question was raised for the first time before us and it was not hinted even in the statement of case filed by the State. In the circumstances, we would not be justified in allowing the respondents to sustain the order of the Custodian-General on the said basis. Even otherwise it would be of no avail to the respondent in the present case. [...] We have held that s. 58 3 does not affect the previous operation of the law and therefore cannot affect the finality of the orders made under the Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedurally not raised below or in pleadings; substantively, finality prevails regardless of jurisdictional defect under prior law.

holdings.text: The order of the Custodian-General dated February 1, 1958 is set aside and the order of the Custodian dated June 6, 1949 is restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the Custodian-General is set aside and that of the Custodian dated June 6, 1949, is restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on lack of revisional jurisdiction due to broken deeming chain and preserved finality under s.58(3).

precedents.citation: Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi 1 . There, on February 23, 1948, an application was made to the Custodian of Evacuee s Property for confirmation of the transaction of exchange under s. 5-A of the East Punjab Evacuees Administration of Property Act, 1947, as amended in 1948.

precedents.case_name: Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: deeming provisions of repealing ordinances and acts apply to judicial orders as well as administrative acts
precedents.cited_holding: the provision applied to the order in question which was admittedly a judicial order

precedents.citation: Delhi Cloth and General Mills v. Incometax Commissioner Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: In Delhi Cloth and General Mills v. Incometax Commissioner Delhi 1 , a similar question arose for consideration. There, on references made to, the High Court under s. 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the High Court made orders before April 1, 1926.

precedents.case_name: Delhi Cloth and General Mills v. Income-tax Commissioner Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of a statute touching a right in existence at the passing of the statute are not to be applied retrospectively absent express enactment or necessary intendment
precedents.cited_holding: provisions which, if applied retrospectively, would deprive of their existing finality Orders which, when the statute came into force, were final, touch existing rights

precedents.citation: Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving 1

anchor.surface_text: Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving 1 thus at p. 290 While provisions of a statute dealing merely with matters of procedure may properly, unless that construction be textually inadmissible, have retrospective effect attributed to them, provisions which touch a right in existence at the passing of the statute are not to be applied retrospectively in the absence of express enactment or necessary intendment.

precedents.case_name: Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd. v. Irving
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of a statute dealing merely with matters of procedure may have retrospective effect, but provisions touching existing rights do not unless expressly or by necessary intendment

precedents.citation: Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Commissioner, Delhi 2

anchor.surface_text: After considering the decision of the Judicial Committee in Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Commissioner, Delhi 2 the learned Judge proceeded to observe thus at p. 1132 This is obviously so because finality attached to them, the moment orders were passed, prior to the new Act.

precedents.case_name: Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Commissioner, Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: finality of orders prior to new statute cannot be disturbed retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: It is said that. this construction of s. 58 3 is no longer open in view of the authoritative interpretation placed upon the said sub-section by this Court in Indira Sohan Lals case 1 . We have carefully gone through that judgment and we are of the view that the said decision is not only not against the construction placed by us on the said sub- section but also the observations therein support the, same construction.

precedents.case_name: Indira Sohan Lal v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of s. 58(3) of the Act regarding previous operation and deeming of prior actions
precedents.cited_holding: pending actions deemed continued under new law, but distinguished where order final before new Act

precedents.citation: Janki Prasad v. The Custodian, Evacuee Property, Jullundur 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed by learned counsel for the respondents on a judgment of a division bench of the Punjab High Court in Janki Prasad v. The Custodian, Evacuee Property, Jullundur 1 . There, an order confirming the sale effected by an evacuee was made by the Assistant Custodian on February 25,1949, and the said order was confirmed by the Additional Custodian on February 28, 1949.

precedents.case_name: Janki Prasad v. The Custodian, Evacuee Property, Jullundur
precedents.cited_proposition: prior order deemed made under 1950 Act allowing review under s.26
precedents.cited_holding: by fiction the earlier order must be deemed to have been made under the Act of 1950
